ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Matthew Baird Archer  This isn't a question - not sure what I'm supposed to write here
Instructor: Matthew Baird Archer  TA did not provide many comments on my assignments, so hard to assess.
Instructor: Matthew Baird Archer  Matthew Archer

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Class was great and some fine tuning of structure and assignment mix will make it even better.

This class worked really well for students in similar social sciences field. It was a valuable opportunity to learn from other students' fields and writing styles as well as provide additional incentives to finish the thesis on time. The only drawback was taking the class with fewer students in my own discipline. While the instructor and TA's feedback was very helpful, comments from students were less so. The class also counted as 4 credits with an outside writing group. My group could never organize to meet, despite my best efforts, and I feel that we still put a lot of work into the class, even without the meetings.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The course provided a structure and deadlines to help me get my writing done. Having the opportunity to critique other students' work was helpful in seeing the strengths and areas for improvement in my own work. Workshopping the presentations was particularly useful to me and a good opportunity to work on my presentation skills and figure out how to communicate my research succinctly.
Generally the course forces the student to really immerse him-/herself in the writing process although the amount of output may have been heavier compared to my other courses.

Course is incredibly helpful in writing up master's research and pushing to publish or present work to external audiences. I benefited a lot from track-change comments on abstract/paper sections from people outside my group. Professor comments were also detailed and incredibly helpful. Even more mandated switching with classmates would be beneficial.
Extra incentive to finish writing; practicing the MESc Colloquium presentation; outside thoughts and opinions on my thesis
The deadlines, work shopping pieces, presentation practice
Receiving detailed comments on written work.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Some of the readings were probably not necessary
I think there really is a need for students to be heavily invested in writing and I would be bias in saying that it would been preferable if this specifically tailored to MESc students.

I might structure the course assignments differently with much of the prep work in the first 2 weeks and then mandatory weekly 500 word submissions thereafter. Or perhaps the prep-work could be a 1 credit reading group in the fall, so that the spring would be all writing/revising. It would be great to have a partner fall course on data analysis and visualizations.Also, I am a hands-on learner, so more discussion of actual articles/presentations would be more helpful than discussing these in generalities. It was a lot to have to review two papers each week and contribute to your own writing -- at times this was too much. Perhaps a smaller class size and more thoughtful assembly of writing groups would be beneficial.
Student feedback not always the most relevant; dedicating a whole class to 3 people's work seemed a bit long at times, but dinner breaks definitely helped.
The writing groups fell apart after spring break. I don't think the final draft deadline should have been removed but maybe adjusted.

Sometimes I felt like the in-class workshops were not extremely helpful for the writes. Perhaps the workshop portion could be divided into two groups based on focus(?) so that people can really dive deeply into each others work (though this is also the purpose of the outside group).

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
Though there was no discussion, my group often used course material / lectures to examine each others work.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: I didn't manage to get to any office hours - my own fault - but Matthew was very available should I have wanted to. His contributions in class were helpful, as were his comments on my written submissions.

Instructor: Matthew Baird Archer  I hardly feel that the TA was invested in the work of the students and it showed in the way his comments were given with the output of the students on a weekly basis. I strongly recommend that the TA in future classes be really broadly exposed to different researches to provide sufficiently in-depth perspectives on how students can better come up with great writing.
Instructor: Matthew Baird Archer  TA didn't provide many comments on my writing pieces. Felt as though was pulling me in a different disciplinary direction that wasn't as helpful.

Instructor: Matthew Baird Archer  Matthew often appeared disengaged in class and I often wish he would speak up more. His comments were also often very specific to his field and not necessarily helpful.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course was the ideal forum for me to get my thesis written, providing structure via deadlines, and encouragement via classmates' and course leaders' feedback.

As an MESc, the need to write and have peers evaluate my writing is valuable. Hence, an opportunity to have a course or some other means by which I can hone my skills is something that should be essential in the MESc program.
Course fits program in rounding out methods and theory courses to create a final product from my master's research.

This is a good option for students that need to write a Master's thesis, as very few guidelines are posted anywhere. It helped motivate me to write and finish in a timely manner that surprised even my advisor.
This course was foundational in helping me examine my research and form it into a cohesive publishable article.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To get my thesis written and learn how to write a journal article
I am writing a master's research and I believe that a course that builds on my research course is valuable as both review and guide in how I move forward in my writing.
I took this course to produce a final piece of writing from my independent master's research that could be shared externally.
To support writing my thesis.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes

Substantially met my expectations although the nuances that the instructor presented were very Western and may not always be understandable to non-American students. I would appreciate that there be a more international perspective to how the course is presented.
Yes, though I wish I had been able to keep on schedule with writing I the early part of the semester.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantages: Opportunity for more feedback on my own work, and to learn from others' work by providing feedbackDisadvantages: When other members of the group were less prepared for our meetings, it didn't feel such a good use of my time

The group generally commented on each other's writing as well as help push everyone to keep on writing. We held regular weekly meetings but the meetings were not always clear as to the output we needed or wanted. It would be more helpful if there was more structure to the meetings.

Writing group was helpful but not as disciplined as it should have been. I wish more structure or diversity was built into the groups instead of self-selection. Weekly 500 word assignments might have helped this out.
I think other writing groups worked well. Mine involved students outside of the class and it was very difficult to convince everyone to organize and meet for the writing group.

Unfortunately, my group was often disengaged with the group process which meant that it was not all that helpful. Observing other groups, I can see that this has the potential to be a great asset for students writing their thesis.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: If you need to get some academic writing done, take this class!

I would highly recommend this course to MEScs as the writing and peer evaluation are valuable before eventually publishing or submitting a thesis. It would be critical that the student have a clear intent on his or her research. I would especially recommend the course to those who are graduating or finishing their thesis on the semester when this will be taken.
Definitely take this course if you want a good pathway and support network for writing up your research.
Spend fall semester preparing / reviewing your data so you don't waste time in Spring. Writing takes time!
